Comment: Naomi Klein herself has something to say about your characterization.   https://www.democracynow.org/2023/9/14/naomi_klein_doppelganger  "I am perennially confused and conflated with another writer named Naomi, Naomi Wolf, and having that identity confusion is an extreme form of uncanniness, because what becomes unfamiliar is you. You see people and hear people talking about you, but it‚Äôs not you. It‚Äôs very destabilizing. So I thought, ‚ÄúWell, this is an interesting technique.‚Äù And she really is less the subject of the book than a literary technique to get into these other kinds of uncanny forces. Should I tell the bathroom story, Amy? ... "I was at a march through the Financial District at the height of Occupy Wall Street. And like other people at that march, I needed to use a public restroom. And I was in one of these skyscrapers, and I don‚Äôt remember exactly which building. But while in the restroom, I overheard a couple of people talking about me, being quite unkind, I must say, Amy. They were sort of drawling, like, ‚ÄúDid you read that article by Naomi Klein? Oh my god, she really doesn‚Äôt understand our movement. She doesn‚Äôt understand our demands.‚Äù And I was sort of frozen in fear. It brought back all of my terrible high school memories, you know, these mean girls who were talking about me.  "But as I listened, I realized, ‚ÄúOh, they‚Äôre not talking about me. They‚Äôre talking about somebody else.‚Äù So I came out of the stall, and I met one of their eyes, and I said words that I have had to say, unfortunately, too many times: ‚ÄúI think you‚Äôre talking about Naomi Wolf.‚Äù But in the end, that became quite fitting to me, because I think when we overhear people speaking about us on social media, we essentially are just reading the graffiti on the bathroom wall, which is not healthy, and we probably should stop doing that. So I think it‚Äôs fitting that the first time I became aware of the identity confusion in the real world, it was actually literally in a bathroom. ... "Well, this is a little tricky to say, because I do write ‚Äî I don‚Äôt think this gives people a pass, but Wolf is one of these people who has experienced a lot of shaming and kind of pile-ons on left Twitter, or liberal Twitter, or X, or whatever it‚Äôs called. She‚Äôs really been, I would say, internet-bullied. People can say, ‚ÄúOK, well, for good reason. She‚Äôs spread conspiracies. She has made major factual errors in her books.‚Äù But I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs necessarily a justification for cruelty. So I think that‚Äôs something else that gets magnified, because I think when people have an experience that is very, very negative in left or liberal circles, where they really get treated almost like they‚Äôre not human ‚Äî and that‚Äôs partly because they‚Äôre performing themselves as a brand, which is saying, ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm out here, I‚Äôm a commodity, I‚Äôm a thing,‚Äù and then people start thinking, ‚ÄúWell, if you‚Äôre a thing, I can throw things at you, and you won‚Äôt bleed‚Äù ‚Äî you know, I think that that‚Äôs part of what is magnified here, and that becomes a justification for, I think, an unjustifiable political alliance with extremely dangerous figures who are building a network of far-right political parties, who take issues like rightful suspicion of Big Pharma, rightful anger at Big Tech, rightful anger at the elites, and flip it to transphobia, xenophobia, racism. And here I‚Äôm thinking about figures like Giorgia Meloni, who is a prot√©g√© of Steve Bannon‚Äôs. ... "[W]hen I would confess to people I knew that I was working on this book, sometimes I would get this strange reaction like, ‚ÄúWell, why would you give [Wolf] attention?‚Äù And there was this sense that because she was no longer visible in the pages of The New York Times or on MSNBC or wherever, and because she had been deplatformed on social media, that ‚Äî or on the social media that we‚Äôre on ‚Äî that she just didn‚Äôt exist. And there was this assumption that we, whoever ‚Äúwe‚Äù are, are in control of the attention, and so if the spigot gets turned off, then there‚Äôs no more attention."  I think the main take-away is that in not seeing these people as people, we can alienate them and they will turn to dangerous movements because they feel seen/heard in them by design. These movements are designed to take those who feel alienated by the left and turn them into right-wing extremists. As Klein herself says, it's tricky, because you don't wanna give people who say/do dangerous things a pass, but at the same time, you don't want to alienate them by dehumanizing them, for example by talking cruelly about them. Maybe it's the views that should be targeted, rather than the people. It's hard though. Just something to consider.
